title: The Structured Singular Value and μ-Analysis
abstract: This paper was published as Advanced techniques for clearance of flight control laws / (eds.) Christopher Fielding ... [et al.], pp. 37-55. Series: Lecture notes in control and information sciences ; 283.  It is available from http://www.springerlink.com/content/tvnjb87lragl3b5x/.  Doi: 10.1007/3-540-45864-6_3Metadata only entryWe introduce the structured singular value μ and discuss its use as an analysis tool for flight control applications. To apply μ-analysis tools to flight control law clearance problems, linear fractional transformation (LFT) based uncertainty models must first be generated to capture the effect of uncertain aircraft parameters on the closed-loop system dynamics. The clearance criteria which are most easily addressed with μ-analysis are those which are defined in the frequency domain such as the stability margin criterion or the unstable eigenvalue criterion. μ-analysis tools which have been developed to address these specific clearance criteria are discussed

The Structured Singular Value and μ-Analysis</dc:title><dc:creator>
Bates, D.G.</dc:creator><dc:creator>
Postlethwaite, Ian</dc:creator><dc:description>
This paper was published as Advanced techniques for clearance of flight control laws / (eds.) Christopher Fielding ... [et al.], pp. 37-55. Series: Lecture notes in control and information sciences ; 283.  It is available from http://www.springerlink.com/content/tvnjb87lragl3b5x/.  Doi: 10.1007/3-540-45864-6_3</dc:description><dc:description>
Metadata only entry</dc:description><dc:description>
We introduce the structured singular value μ and discuss its use as an analysis tool for flight control applications. To apply μ-analysis tools to flight control law clearance problems, linear fractional transformation (LFT) based uncertainty models must first be generated to capture the effect of uncertain aircraft parameters on the closed-loop system dynamics. The clearance criteria which are most easily addressed with μ-analysis are those which are defined in the frequency domain such as the stability margin criterion or the unstable eigenvalue criterion. μ-analysis tools which have been developed to address these specific clearance criteria are discussed.</dc:description><dc:date>
